required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: The Effect of Pork With Modified Fat Composition and Berries on Plasma Fatty Acids and Fecal Compounds in Healthy Adults
clinical_study.official_title: The Effect of Pork With Modified Fatty Acid Composition on Plasma Lipids and Fatty Acids and the Effect of Pork and Berries on Fecal Compounds in Healthy Adults

brief_summary.textblock:
High consumption of red meat is related to cardiovascular diseases. Red meat containing more unsaturated fat than normal red meat may have a beneficial impact on plasma lipid and fatty acid profile in humans. Furthermore, consumption of red meat and especially processed red meat is considered harmful to colon health. However, consumption of fruit and berries rich in antioxidants and flavonoids may provide protection when red meat is consumed.
The study aims to answer whether the fatty acid profile of pork when modified towards more unsaturated fat will affect plasma fatty acids and lipids in adult volunteers. The effects of pork with a modified fatty acid content is compared with conventional pork with lower unsaturated fat content. Fatty acid composition of pork is modified by altering the composition of animal feed.
The other arm of the study investigates the effects of consuming berries together with red meat on gut metabolism. The study focuses on how berries affect the formation of fecal compounds known to be related to high red meat consumption, such as N-nitroso compounds.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in plasma fatty acids as a measure of dietary fatty acid modification
Change in fecal nitroso compounds as a measure of increased (processed) red meat consumption
primary_outcome.description: Measured as apparent total nitroso compounds (ATNC)

primary_outcome.measure: Genotoxicity testing of human fecal water in 3D cell culture
primary_outcome.description: Fecal water is isolated from fecal samples collected before and after the intervention period from arms B and C. The samples are tested for markers of genotoxicity in 3D cell culture.

secondary_outcome.measure: Changes in plasma lipids as a measure of dietary modification
secondary_outcome.description: Concentrations of and changes in total cholesterol, LDL-cholesterol, HDL-cholesterol, triglycerides are measured before and after the intervention period

secondary_outcome.measure: Concentration of polyphenolics in fecal water as a measure of consumption of berries
secondary_outcome.description: The polyphenol content of the fecal water is assessed from arms B and C

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in hemoglobin as a measure of dietary modification
Change in blood pressure as a measure of dietary modofcation
secondary_outcome.description: Blood pressure is measured before and after the study period.

secondary_outcome.measure: Weight development during the study period
secondary_outcome.description: The subjects are weighed before and after the study and their weight is monitored weekly during the study

arm_group.description: Pork with modified fatty acid composition, more unsaturated fat. 160 g pork or pork products daily for 4 weeks, consumption of other red meat is prohibited
Normal pork 160 g pork or pork products daily for 4 weeks, consumption of other red meat is prohibited
Normal pork and berries (strawberry, raspberry, wild blueberry, lingonberry, cloudberry, blackcurrant) 160 g pork or pork products daily for 4 weeks, consumption of other red meat is prohibited

intervention.description: Pork with modified fatty acid composition
intervention.other_name: Pork with modified fatty acid composition and berries

intervention.description: Pork with normal fat composition and Finnish berries

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- diet includes meat
Exclusion Criteria:
- high consumption of fish (4 times per week)
- use of fish oil/ omega-3 oil capsules one month before the intervention
- hypercholesterolemia
- vegetarian, vegan

overall_official.affiliation: Division of Nutrition, Department of Food and Environmental Sciences, University of Helsinki
Division of Nutrition, Department of Food and Environmental Sciences, University of Helsinki

facility.name: Division of Nutrition, University of Helsinki
